abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Basic Education Project
            for Niger were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank performance
            was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: provision of
            school places is not enough to promote access. Targeted
            interventions are sometimes needed to address specific
            constraints of some groups. The use of ERAs (Ecole Rurale
            Alternative - Alternative Rural Schools) and the tutoring
            programs for girls was used effectively in this project.
            Demand side issues also need to be addressed to complement
            provision of school places. Community involvement in the
            management of schools is a key factor for success as
            demonstrated by the activities of the COGES (Comite de
            Gestion des Etablissements Scolaires - School Management
            Committee). Reforms aimed at reducing the period of teacher
            training on the assumption that teachers already have basic
            knowledge of subject contents should first be verified
            before implementation. This will help avoid inadequate
            training and the reversal of this policy as happened in
            Niger. When models based on adaptations of local technology
            that could be sensitive are proposed, such as the steel
            framed construction of schools, these models should be fully
            discussed and agreed with all stakeholders, including the
            wider public, before they are implemented to avoid
            unexpected reversals of policy. Decentralization of
            education management especially to local/school levels
            should be accompanied by a clearly worked out fiduciary
            management system that will ensure proper use and
            accountability of funds to minimize the risk of leakage and
            suspension of the reform. During preparation and appraisal
            every effort should be made to adopt uniform arrangements
            for implementation. If this could not be done then the risks
            associated with the use of different procedures should be
            assessed and included in the appraisal/ approval process.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Basic Education Project for
            Niger's objectives are: (i) to increase enrollment and
            completion in basic education programs and (ii) to improve
            management at all levels by improving the use of existing
            resources, focusing on rural areas to achieve greater equity
            and poverty reduction in the medium to long term.  The
            Project has three components.  The first, to improve access
            to primary education will have three subcomponents: support
            to primary school construction and renovation program in
            rural areas; improve girl's education; and an adult
            literacy program.  The second component, to improve the
            quality and efficiency of primary and lower secondary
            education,  will have five subcomponents: improve
            pre-service and in-service teacher training in primary
            education; improve availability of pedagogical inputs in
            primary and lower secondary education (textbooks and
            materials); innovative targeted learning programs for
            alternative rural schools (pilot) and tutoring programs for
            under-performing students in targeted areas (pilot); and
            institutionalize the evaluation of learning outcomes. The
            third component, to strengthen management capacity of the
            Ministry of Education (MOE) and empower local entities and
            communities,  will have four subcomponents: improvements to
            MOE including strengthening organization and HR capacity;
            improve and/or develop core management systems; strengthen
            the capacity of school management committees (COGES);
            provide support to the preparation of the second block of
            the ten-year program and other core studies.

repnme.cdata!:
Analyse Environnementale et Sociale de la
            Phase 1 Du Project Education de Base au Niger

abstracts.cdata!:
The Basic Education Project for Niger
            aims to improve access to education, teaching quality, and
            to improve learning conditions. The program objectives are
            to build and renovate primary schools as well as putting in
            place water infrastructure and health facilities. The
            environmental and social impact study shows only minor
            negative impacts on the physical and social environment of
            the rural and urban areas. A degradation of sites and
            quarries is expected as a result of collecting building
            materials, the destruction of vegetation will occur in
            school building process and, relative loss of animal
            biodiversity in these sites. Negative impacts are varied and
            dispersed in the environment and it will be difficult to
            measure which part of these negative impacts is due to
            school building sites and restoration formulas that would be
            easy to maters and follow up. The negative impacts on the
            natural resources related to the program and which can be
            controlled by the program are: the destruction of vegetation
            on the new school building sites, the pollution of
            excavations left by quarries especially in the rainy season,
            erosion in borrowed sites and work sites waste management.
            Mitigation measures include: tree-planting in school grounds
            and surroundings and, excavations left by quarries must be
            filled in before the rainy season to avoid pollution. A
            detailed technical study of sanitary facilities (school
            latrines) and compost enclosures for school waste management
            is recommended.

repnme.cdata!:
Niger - Basic Education Project :
            resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Basic Education Project for
            Niger's development objective is to build and renovate
            primary schools, as well as put in place water and sanitary
            infrastructures, and health facilities. However, since
            building of these infrastructures imply involuntary
            temporary or permanent displacement of populations,
            annexation of farming land, and the expropriation of private
            or community holdings, this Political Resettlement Framework
            aims to formulate principles for resettlement and
            compensation, specify which institutional mechanisms and
            procedures are to be applied. Based on the laws of the Niger
            as well as the Bank's operational directive on
            involuntary resettlement, the following recommendations are
            given: preparation of a socio-economic study; define three
            eligibility criteria for property and revenue restoration;
            adopt a consultative approach all along the process with the
            populations affected; develop an information and
            communications strategy; and in the event of dispute, define
            the dispute settlement document, favoring transparency,
            equity and promptitude of settlement. The report establishes
            principle and procedures related to populations displacement
            and compensation, focusing on vulnerable groups, proposed a
            participatory approach and guarantees the affected
            populations that they will recover their rights.
